Name: The Quantum World: Quantum Physics for Everyone

ReviewList.Text: This book is pure pleasure.  It reads a bit like an adventure story as the author explains how the concepts of the quantum theory were developed to make sense of experimental results in the subatomic realm.  The author's engaging style makes quantum theory seem almost easy!  This book is by far the best effort to bring the meaning of quantum theory to the nonscientist that I have read

I'm a mathematical retard, but this book is making sense!!  If you are a visual person, who is better able to figure 'things' out if you can 'see' them, get this book.  I'm an English major, but this book is helping me to 'see' quantum theory!!

I enjoyed it, but then again, I'm a quantum physics major.  It really deals more with particle physics to begin with, and only later brings quantum into sight.  I still thought it was easy reading, though, and still entertaining.  It kept my attention.  However, for an easy introduction into quantum physics, I still feel that Jim Al-Khalili's book "Quantum" is a better read.

I know nothing of the quantum world so I picked up this book and to my amazement, I can actually understand most of it so far.  I haven't read all of it yet, but its basically and introduction into the field and the author breaks down what he's talking about into examples so you understand it. I'd definitely recommend this book to anyone who has an interest in quantum physics, physics, or even science.  Very interesting book.
This is the best overview of quantum theory that I've read. Lucid, concise, and, amazingly, very inclusive at the same time.
The Kindle edition has many missing pictures and diagrams.  In their place are the words, "[To view this image, refer to the print version of this title.]"  Really???

I found this book to be very interesting. The only minor drawback is the intense focus on the many kinds of sub-atomic particles (Hadrons, Fermions, Leptons, Pions, W particles, etc.), but I really liked the way the information was presented. A good book for the non-scientist. Makes the completely complicated quantum theory quasi-understandable, if not fathomable. I think it was Neils Bohr you said that something like "anybody who claims to understand quantum mechanics really doesn't", as it is weird science based on probabilities. Not many equations in the book; a few in the footnotes.

This book is obviously targeted at the layman -- it's not a textbook.  It makes very few assumptions about the reader's background -- but from a practical perspective, a reader with some appreciation for basic physics will get more from the book.  What amazes me is just how much territory the author covers, using a very informal and approachable style.  It's thoughtful exposition, not just a perfunctory review of the facts.  In my opinion this is one of the best "introductory" books on quantum physics.

The book is great in trying to understand the many terms in Quantum Mechanics. For some reason, many images and digrams are missing in the electronic version.  Hopefully the next electronic edition can address this problem.

This is a great book that explains many things better than most of hte Q books I have read. Not may books explain quantum spin and number as well as this book.  The author uses good analogies for most of his points that really bring the reader in and help establish the concepts.  Highly recommended.

The book is great. Fundamental ideas of the quantum mechanics are explained in plain, clear and concise language. I think the book can be useful to undergraduate students who take a course on modern physics or a basic quantum mechanics course. I read "The Quantum World" in parallel with University Physics and Modern Physics and found this reading very enjoyable. But as a popular reading this book may be rather complicated. To people who don't have a relevant background in physics, before starting this book I would recommend "Warped passages" by Lisa Randall or "The Fabric of the Cosmos" by Brian Greene.

After reading about 1/4 of this book, I had to put it down. Reading all the positive reviews of this book, I thought I would be getting a clear understanding of quantum mechanics. That was not the case at all. The author goes on and on about the particles in the atom (the are many), which is interesting, but doesn't give one a general understanding of quantum mechanics. I majored in Geophysics in college, so there was no difficulty for me to follow the man and physics in this book. It just is not the one to read if you want a general understanding of the stangeness of quantum mechanics.

This book deals mostly with the quantum facts and doesn't deal with the underlying reality interpretations in depth. It is written very clearly with lots of analogies, however the mass and depth of information make it a studious read, though it is easy to get many basic ideas with a skim. It has a lot of history of quantum discoveries and the people that made them. I like this book.

i have minimal background in quantum mechanics and this book, while complex at times, did not really lose me.  i think it is a very good intro book on the subject and though i still have a lot of questions (though i think everyone who looks into quantum mechanics will), i feel that i have a much better understanding of the basics.

I liked this book. I'm on my third re-read. Not because it's poorly written, on the contrary it's very well written. It's because this is a very abstract science, and asks one to really stretch your imagination to the limits. The author does a good job of illustrating several points. He does sort of get ahead of himself rather rapidly, especially when it comes to listing particles, their properties which he does rapidly left and right. He should spend more time on spin properties, a bit more nuts and bolts with quarks in my opinion. These parts are why I'm re-reading it. I pick up something new each time I do however and I don't fault the author for this either. I dont' consider myself brilliant but I do like this science so maybe if my IQ were higher I might have "picked it all up" on the first pass? Anyway it doesn't contain lots of nice diagrams, the ones that are in the book look like someone scrawled them on the face of a napkin. But still it gets the point across. If you want a book with nice pretty graphs, tons of formulas and math then don't buy this. As the title says in the last few words "for Everyone." Those two words automatically remove lots of math from the contents. Most folks I know have trouble with math if they don't have their cell phones handy. I learned a great deal more than I knew before about this science from this book. I certainly learned more from it than listening to Pamela Gay on Astronomy Cast complain that this science "hurts her head."  It's a good book. It has lots of pictures of important physicist, Enrico Fermi, Wolfgang Pauli, Paul Dirac, etc. I like to put a face with the names. One review said this book is "NOT" an easy way into this science. There is no "easy" way into this realm. It confounds the best minds at times. This is a subject that is difficult to understand by the human mind so it goes with explaining it to layfolk as well. I suggest just jumping into this if you are interested in the quantum world. This book is about as easy as it gets, you might not think so after reading it, but the author does a good job of explaining most of it. If you are like me you'll want to read other opinions and facts on quantum mechanics. This book is a good starting place in my opinion.

I should say that my expectations from this book were high enough, expecially when looking at the average rating and the editorial review. Now, I don't feel disappointed strictly speaking, but I find claims such as: "A TOP, A MUST!" a bit of overstatements. Mr. Ford was accurate in describing the basics of the Standard Model in the quantum framework, and some of his translations of quantum ideas in the common sense world are nice and useful but, in the average, nohow his work hovers above a host of similar books devoted to the same subject. So, read it if you are interested in quantum physics and all that, and you have some previous knowledge of the topic (otherwise, if you are a real layman, you risk to get lost in the first 20 pages or so); it is fair but, at least in my opinion (I am a professional astrophysicist, and a popularizer in Italian language), just fair.

I loved this book from start to finish. The material is fascinating and presented clearly, in easy-to-digest form. In terms of the reader's assumed knowledge, this book doesn't aim for the *lowest* common denominator. Some familiarity with first-year algebra is helpful, but not essential; the concepts generally stand on their own without any mathematics at all. Ford also explains the experiments that led to many aspects of the standard model, particularly from earlier developments. This helps the reader appreciate the evidence physicists were weighing in their attempts to piece together the puzzle. If anything, I would have appreciated more details on these experiments. But, for a quick introduction to the topic, this book does a fine job balancing the information and does an exceptional job getting the reader to visualize concepts.

I've taken a lot of time reading this book because I've also read some other treatments in between (Gribbins, Feynman, etc).  I took physics in college but that was long ago.  This book is a good reference book because it surveys the QM world very well.  It may not cover a lot of more subtle issues but it's a good first read I think.  The appendix helps to order the particles in your mind.  I keep getting terms mixed up like bosons & fermions.  It's really just a matter of familiarity and memory refresh.

good book to review the basics. however, i was looking for a book for my aged parents to explain in laymans terms the mysteries of quantum mechanics. for example, the double slit experiment that suggests particles can be in two or more places at the same time. i was looking and still am looking for a book for laypeople that would explain enough about quantum mechanics to make them say 'wow!' but not go into great detail about leptons and their spin.

I really wanted to like and enjoy this book.  I am interested in quantum physics and hoped this book would be fairly easy to understand for the average reader.  I am no genius, but I am no dummy either, but this book is very dry and hard to follow.  I appreciate Kenneth Ford's attempt to present quantum physics in a easy-to-follow manner, but in my opinion, he fails to do so.  I do not think it is a poorly written book, and I have certainly garnered some interesting information from the book.  However, I was hoping to find the book easy to understand, and enjoy reading it, instead of finding it tedious.

Though I often found myself lost at times, and unable to keep track of all the technical terms, this book taught me a lot about the current quantum theory. I now stare into space thinking of cosmic foam and ponder the meaning of superposition states. If you like quantum physics (and who doesn't?!) I guess I recommend it. I enjoyed it anyway. My review may not mean much though considering I'm no physicist.
He has very lucid language for some complex phenomenon and used it perfectly to give an idea about quantum mechanics, but would exect a book for people with some level of mathematical training

This is an excellent primer. Great coverage of the terminology, which is extensive in this topic. What little math there is is not algebraic nor calculus. It has some basic equations around the conservation of energy issues. I recommend for the person just getting into the quantum physics subject matter.

This was a very short, enjoyable, non-mathematical overview of the history and core concepts of quantum mechanics.  Highly recommended if you want a taste, but you don't want to devote too much time to it.  I also recommend reading the book and doing related keyword searches on YouTube for videos that reinforce the concepts in a visual way, especially for teachers, e.g., the book talks about the search for the Higgs boson, but in 2012 this was finally detected with the CERN Large Hadron Collider in Switzerland, and there are many videos related to this.

I read this book earlier in the year, and just finished Mr. Ford's 101 Questions book. The thing I liked best about this book, is that it filled in so many gaps that other books on this subject either left out or didn't explain well. It's a little long for the layman, but that isn't a con, just an observation. This was the fourth book I've read on this subject, but the first to really enlighten me about quantum mechanics. I highly recommend this book, and suggest that the layman also read Mr. Ford's 101 Questions book.

Easy to read if you already have a basic understanding of quantum theory. Kenneth W. Ford does a great job of explaining in detail the topics and history of quantum theory. The apendices are helpful, but it would be nice to have a complete standard model flowchart in one of them. Over all it's a great read if you want to know all about the subatomic particles and the forces that govern them.

Bought this book in the heels of buying the graphic guide to relativity. Recommended for readers who don't care to learn the math to understand the concepts. The kind of book you'll re-read to grasp the concepts instead of putting down to look elsewhere.
Has to be good if I managed to understand most of it.  Suggest this to the part-time physicists out there.

I have a background in chemistry so I have taken courses in quantum chemistry. I bought this book as a review since I haven't read anything on quantum physics for awhile and needed a refresher course. I found this book a little simple, but it is for everyone. If you don't have any experience in the field, I highly recommend this book.

For a person with math phobia, this was a good book on a mysterious and interesting subject. He has the equations to prove his point, but he also does a good job of explaining the issues, so I could follow the unfolding debate.
I purchased this book for my teenage grandson who has shown an interest in science. According to him, the book does a great job in explaining quantum physics in an easy-to-understand manner.
I have found this book very easy to read and understand. It is great for people who want to know things regarding physics without a 'gob' of formulas to be confused with.
I will be using this book i a seminar on the subject matter. I feel it will be just right for the kind of people in the group. Kenneth Ford is a superb author.
Very clear explanations with some great analogies of a tough subject.  Brought my understanding of quantum mechanics forward by 40 years.
The book can on the 3 day. It also was packaged perfectly with the right size box. One of the best books on quantum physics.
Nice book about stuff I know nothing about but my fiancé loves stuff like this and she loves this book!
Awesome book for all levels. This is actually the second copy I got as my original got damaged
great book

great bookgreat book great book, great book, great book, great book great book great book, great book, great book, great book great book great book, great book, great book, great bookgreat book great book, great book, great book, great book great book great book, great book, great book, great book great book great book, great book, great book, great book
Has the right amount of technical content. Not too simplistic for people usually interested in the subject, who naturally have some technical background. Interesting and entertaining style.

Just received notice from my grandson that the middle pages are inserted upside down and some are missing.  Unfortunately I was notified of this past the return date.  This is not a problem that would be obvious when the book was received but only when the reader reaches the problem.  It would be nice if it could be replaced with a complete book.

Instead of pictures and graphs, you fine text that says you must look at the printed version to see the pictures!  What a pain.  If I had the printed version, I wouldn't need this one.  I want my money back.

This book isn't poorly organized or written, it just hasn't had the rough edges smoothed out. It has some continuity problems in building the framework for the reader to place ideas into context, undefined terms, etc. Its not bad (and it is very basic), but there are probably better ones out there.

For the sake of humanity and the future, this man ought NEVER to have been born.  It is a further insult that he came from a wealthy family with provenance and worked for the government in secret.  I don't know how he lives with himself.  Oh, could it be he is perhaps a sociopath?
